Fields.DialogueText: Mon Dieu, Capitaine, have you seen this madness!?
Hello, Triomphant. No, I'm not busy. Please come in and sit down.
Now is hardly the time for sarcasm, Capitaine! But I shall sit down if it makes you so happy.
It does. Now, I'll assume you're upset about the latest intelligence reports we've gotten from our civilian coastal areas nearby? Regarding the ongoing propaganda war?
It seems Despair and those like her simply won't quit... I'm wondering if Despair has a sister ship named Doubt, and another named Discordia.
Still, of all things. The people... don't believe in Belles? But many have seen us, spoken to us... was not my voice carried to the entire French coast? Even parts of England.
I simply do not understand how this can be. Capitaine? What do you think of all of this?

Fields.MenuText: I'll be honest: I have trouble believing you're not some dream born of desperation at times.
People can't comprehend what they don't understand. Sailors have an inherent understanding of Belles, because ships have always had a spirit to us.
They're being fed lies by the Morganas. They don't have to "understand" the women on the radio who bring death, but they know they're real, and we can't be everywhere.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph. I would certainly hope you of all people would know by now that I at least am very real, though I shall consider it flattery that I could be the woman of your dreams.
A fair point, and one the enemy is clearly exploiting. So how can we counter that? We need people to know we're real.
So it may even look like we're losing this war already. I suppose that would make it easy to write Belles off as propaganda.
All told, this will not stand! I cannot accept it, nor shall I, especially not from the likes of Despair and her ilk. We must defeat them! At sea and in the hearts of the people.
I thought you'd say that. Any ideas?
Non... not immediately, anyway. I shall send a telegram to Monsieur Lockhart when we next make port. Hopefully he will have some suggestions.
I still have some of the equipment aboard, so even just sending back some scripts by courier or naval mail would be of great help.
Let's just hope the old man responds quickly.
@BATTLE
It appears the problem might be worse than I thought.
Our morale problem among the civilian populace?
In certain theaters, yes.
One of the sailors got a rather blistering letter from his own mother because he had the audacity to mention some goings-on aboard ship that included me.
If she thinks a letter from her own son has been run through the propaganda mill to perpetuate this "falsehood" of the Belles... what can we truly do against that?

Fields.MenuText: You know, it's probably not the Belles they don't believe in, but the whole story. The Morgana, an international fleet fighting for all of humanity...
They believe in miracles, but they don't want to believe in situations that mean we need miracles.
I don't know if we're going to be able to change the minds of a stubborn old woman with words alone.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose it is normal to us. It is what I awoke for, and it is your daily reality.
Yes... confronting the start of a war is hard for many people. Especially a war like the one we face with the Morganas. Humanity has never had such a foe.
You sound like a certain other French Belle... she too prizes action above words, but we are fighting constantly. How can we act in such a way to let the people feel our deeds?
I will hope that Monsieur Lockhart will have answers for us in his reply. In the meantime I shall think on this subject... right after we sort the ruffians on the horizon.
Morganas? Now? Merde. Action stations!
*ALARM*
Merde? I must be rubbing off on your Capitaine.
Tease later, get to the bridge now!
@BATTLE
Right - get the civilians secured below. Bring them food, blankets, the usual. We head straight back to port and get them offloaded.
Right away, Captain.
I heard we picked up survivors from the latest battle.
Correct. The Morganas didn't get a chance to attempt the passenger liner they disabled. It's sinking; there's no fixing that, but we have the passengers safe at least.
Honestly, it's a miracle the ship stayed above water for so long after a torpedo to the keel.
Her spirit is strong. She will hold till the last of the crew have been evacuated. It is a shame... she would make quite a Belle.
Surely you can't believe that nonsense can you?
... Pardon, Madame, could you please repeat that?
A bright girl like you can't possibly buy this nonsense about Belles the papers and radio have been spinning. Even if it does seem they've started letting women crew aboard ships.
I can approve of that at least, but this other propaganda... no, I think we have no need of it. Whatever nation those ships are from, you saw them off just fine without a Belle.
Madame! S'il vous plaît, attendez! Sigh... I am this ship's Belle. She's gone. Never have I had such a moment of confusion, Capitaine!

Fields.MenuText: Well, no one likes being told they don't exist to their face.
Should we go after her? Explain? She's probably in shock at the moment. Give her a minute to rest and...

Fields.DialogueText: It is a bit... upsetting, yes.
Non. She needs to eat and rest, not have her ear talked off by me.
I am more certain than ever, Capitaine. We must do something about this, and quickly.

Fields.MenuText: Some people are just too blind for words.

Fields.DialogueText: Think nothing of it, Capitaine. It is just a matter of finding the right words.
There's the passenger liner. Tread lightly.
We shall hit the Morganas all the harder!
@BATTLE
It's not often I find you drinking straight out of the bottle. What's wrong?
Capitaine... I am sorry you must see me like this, but I received a response from Monsieur Lockhart. He will send some scripts and make broadcasts of his own.
Well, that sounds like good news.
Oui, it is. But he also suggested I need to put myself in the shoes of the people I wanted to reach... Capitaine. Do you know how France suffered in the Great War?
Nearly two million people slaughtered outright, many more left maimed or injured... or suffering maladies of the mind for which we have not found a cure.
Every French family lost at least one family member, and with the French economy in ruins, much of our farmland turned into shell holes and trench lines... so many starved.
And now war has come again. After the war to end all wars... This mad Austrian will not stop with Poland. I do not know if France can withstand the Germans again...
...not like last time. Too much blood spilled in our fields, so many lives cut down like wheat before the scythe. Capitaine... I believe we shall be victorious, that France will survive...
...but the people do not. They cannot. All they know is that enemies come again, and that once again the dead will be most of what is planted, and more death the only harvest.
I do not blame them for this. I cannot. I feel it too, in my heart of hearts, for I too am French; born of French steel, French blood, sweat, and tears. How could I not know?
My heart yearns for triumph. It is who and what I am. But even in victory one is not always triumphant. France knows this more than perhaps any other nation.
Despair is a personal foe, not because she herself attacks France, but because despair itself is an enemy that every Frenchman must face, now more than ever.
Capitaine, I know what I must do, but I know not how to do it. We must give them hope, or these wars, at sea and on land, are already lost. Please. Guide me.

Fields.MenuText: Why is this hitting you so hard? This isn't the Triomphant I know.
Surely you knew all of this before, didn't you?
All of that is a reason to take heart, not whimper with pain. If France survived all that, what can some thrice-cursed sea hags do?

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose it is a matter that I do not... attend to. Some of the other French Belles would chastise me, but I am not a sentinel of the dead like they are. I honor their triumphant spirits.
Yes, but it is not something I think of often, perhaps not something I have let fully... impact me since awakening. Putting myself in their shoes, I understood.
You're right, of course. Thank you, Capitaine. I must not forget which way victory lies.
Still the question remains... how can we give them hope?
All ahead full, Triomphant. Business as usual.
Oui, so it would seem.
@BATTLE
Ah, Capitaine! Bonjour! I just finished broadcasting. I think it went quite well. Monsieur Lockhart has outdone himself with these scripts.
You look to be in much higher spirits than before. If you're feeling down, I know we're really in trouble.
I am glad you are so concerned about me, Capitaine, but I am fine. Even with my momentary... outburst.
I had a critical thought, though. Radio isn't enough. Not even close. Nor are articles in the paper. We need to reach out directly.

Fields.MenuText: That's a hell of a tall order, Triomphant.
It's not like you can go for a stroll about town.
That makes sense. Seeing is believing... though humans frequently don't believe what they see, either.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, Capitaine, but it is what must be done.
Non... it would be much easier if I could send my specter forth from my hull at will, but I cannot.
Perhaps this is a more difficult task than I had first thought. We shall overcome it, though.
Maybe we can do something with television or film.
Perhaps, but I wonder if that might not make it worse... still, we should look into having the INPF film fleet activity and engagements with the Morganas.
@BATTLE
I wish we'd come up with that before! I have a feeling this battle will be one for the theaters...
Capitaine, I'd like to discuss further how we can win the cœurs et esprits, the hearts and minds of the people. We cannot let despair claim them.
That's a sentiment I can certainly get behind. We need civilian support if we're going to succeed.
If we can alleviate morale problems at home, it might bring the sailors peace of mind. That would have a direct fleetwide benefit.
We have to reach out to the people. Let them feel our presence in a tangible way. None of our regular ports probably question Belles, do they?
I... am not sure, but it seems a reasonable hypothesis.
Maybe we should just change up where we make port more often and get the rest of the INPF to do so as well.
I'm not sure that would have the radiating impact we need. We need people to come to us, then go out and spread our message in the countryside.

Fields.MenuText: Wasn't there an American Navy thing that was going out to port towns with a group of ships?
We could send INPF ships to various ports, put on events. Interact with people.
I swear we have a Public Affairs Office for this kind of thing.

Fields.DialogueText: That sounds promising. I shall interview some of the American sailors and officers. Perhaps one of them will know.
That does seem the most obvious course of action.
They clearly aren't doing their jobs terribly well if people can be found that do not believe in Belles.
*ALARM*
Maybe getting your blood up will shake some thoughts loose. Morganas inbound!
It certainly cannot hurt!
@BATTLE
I have it! Fleet week!
A what now?
It's an American event. President Roosevelt started it when he was Secretary of the Navy.
He ordered the top American admiral to assemble one of the largest fleets to sail under the American flag and dock them all in San Diego.
The crews were given shore leave, and provided civilians with tours of their ships, explanations of equipment. I believe there was an air show as well.
It's perfect!  We assemble as many ships as we can - colors flying, sailors in dress uniforms manning the rails - and we put on an open house.
Every little thing I've done, from a concert to a good meal, all of that we can combine into a few days of programming! If we bring one of the carriers we can even...
...demonstrate carrier aviation and do an air show at the time time. The important part will be ships of all nations, as many as possible. The world might be at war...
...but the INPF is humanity united and we must show that United Front. Not just French sailors on French soil, but Americans, Japanese, English, even Germans.
Whoa, okay take a breath. Even if you don't need to breathe, and I'm not sure you do, take a breath. I'm glad you're excited. This sounds like exactly what we needed.

Fields.MenuText: Where should we pick for the test location?
We're going to have to make a strong statement about some of the international crews. There's a few human wars to consider, too.
It's going to be a hell of a fight with HQ to get them to back this, never mind prying the budget out of them.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I am biased in France's favor, of course, and the French coast has been raided heavily by Despair.
We must be clear about the threat the Morganas represent. This war supersedes nations, no matter how we love our homes. Fleet week will make it clear.
Ne vous inquiétez pas, Capitaine. I shall make them see.
I am going to go and dash off a message to the American Navy. Perhaps they can tell me about previous fleet weeks so we can make a budget estimate!
Put a pin in that. We're not alone out here!
@BATTLE
How's the planning coming, Triomphant?
Ah Capitaine! Perfect. I have worked out our general plan of attack for your approval. Because we are embroiled in combat operations, I thought the event should be brief.
So instead of fleet week, a fleet weekend if you will. So far the INPF is willing to help, and will provide a support flotilla.
So I am now planning out and budgeting the events. We should be able to do it quite cheaply beyond the obvious personnel costs.

Fields.MenuText: So what all do you have planned so far?
You sure have generated  a lot of paperwork so far. Make sure to streamline the final plan once you have it.
You know, I think I'm actually a bit excited for this event.

Fields.DialogueText: All manner of things. I thought about international competitions, but decided to make things intership instead.
Of course, Capitaine. I can't present all this to the INPF. It would take longer than the event itself!
I am as well! It should be fun. A nice change of pace from this war.
Could you bring me those papers over... Merde. Morganas!
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
All right, so I have this program of events for the two days. Quite the schedule you have for us.
As in war, so in peace. To win the hearts and minds of the people we must strike with bold and decisive force!
Is that what they call rugby these days? Bold and decisive force? Then again, I suppose rugby is pretty forceful.
So: an opening ceremony with a joint color guard for all nations represented in the fleet. A couple of sporting tournaments, tours, band performance, air show, and two large meals.
Pretty full days, but you weren't kidding when you said you were going to go bring all of your favorite tricks to bear.
But of course! I never do less than my best, and for such a critical task... I must be even better than normal.

Fields.MenuText: Are we missing anything? Maybe a drill competition? Those tend to get civilian attention.
Hmm. Maybe we could do a gunnery demo.
Let's cap the evening off with fireworks as the main body of the fleet departs. End things with a bang.

Fields.DialogueText: I tried already. Such units tend to belong to forces like the American Marines or British Army, and I cannot convince liaisons to even ask for them.
A sound idea. We could offer a limited number of civilians the chance to come out with us, then send the ship firing to just beyond the mouth of the port. Safe and visible for all.
Ah, éclatant! I'll see if I can acquire fireworks and people who know how to use them.
I think everything is finally coming together!
Just in time for the Morganas to try and blast it apart...
@BATTLE
Triomphant. What in the hell is that massive leather book?
It's the first reorganization of the INPF fleet week planning documents into a single convenient volume. I have everything perfectly organized in here.
That's pretty impressive. Tabs for budgets, menus... you've got it all.
Yes, most of this is for our specific fleet week. I will hopefully simplify everything further over my next few free periods.
To be honest, I feel like a bride planning her wedding when I immerse myself in this book.
Would that make me the groom, then?
I... Capitaine! I, uh... I must go!
Unexpected. She was bright red, too.
*ALARM*
Ah, hell.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: You're still bright red. Did what I say earlier upset you that much?
Look, Triomphant I'm sorry. That comment was maybe a bit crass. Please don't be upset.
You know, you're cute when you blush.

Fields.DialogueText: You simply do not understand a maiden's heart, Capitaine!
It... non! Non. It did not upset me it just... surprised me, is all.
Eep. Now you're doing it on purpose, Capitaine!
What's important is that you're comfortable. I'll watch what I say.
Merci, Capitaine. I knew you would see it my way.
... Do I even see it my way?
So, give me an update, Triomphant. How's the event coming?
I am getting very excited, Capitaine! But also nervous. We must succeed, and succeed in such a way that others can replicate our success.
One success simply isn't enough, we must reach many, not just a few.

Fields.MenuText: There will be the radiant word of mouth effect. That will widen our impact.
We'll do it. I have faith in you and in what we can do together.
Let's get one success on the board before we worry about the next.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, but it will not be enough. We must get fleets visiting as many deep-water ports as time and finances allow.
Belief is important. You can't do what you believe you can't.
That is a fair point, Capitaine. I mustn't outrun myself.
There's so much to do with this... especially because I have never done anything like this before.
But that will not stop me! I will triumph over this event and over the Morganas.
That's the spirit. I'm always here if you need me.
I know, Capitaine. Being able to rely on you makes me feel better about all of this.
*ALARM*
Shall we try for that Morgana triumph you promised?
A promise made is a promise kept!
@BATTLE
Zut cette paperasse à l'enfer! There is too much still.
What? What's wrong, Triomphant?
This paperwork! It is terrible no matter how I slay it. I might need to borrow a sword and run it through.
Is all this still the plans for our event?
Non, this is the other half of the work: producing a standard template for anyone in the INPF to follow. It's quite complex!
Allowing for numerous local customs, local cuisines; it has quickly become rather tangled, Capitaine.
Aren't you overthinking all of this a bit?
Que voulez-vous dire? What do you mean Capitaine?

Fields.MenuText: Well, look here: you have what looks to be most of a cookbook. They have cooks of their own. Provide an example menu maybe, but not recipes.
I think they'd have people on hand who know more about local customs than we do. If not, they can ask people in their current locality.
Triomphant, I know you're trying your hardest, but I think half that stack is extra work that you don't need to be doing.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah... you know, thinking about it, that is a bit excessive. What food is appropriate will vary by region as well.
A good point. Now I feel silly for going to all the trouble to track down crew who knew about these things.
...Merde. Thank you Capitaine. It's so easy to get wrapped up in work, especially with a task I am passionate about.
Well now that I have some free time... shall we...
*ALARM*
...sink an enemy fleet. Always with the terrible timing for them.
@BATTLE
Sorry to pull you away from all your planning, Triomphant, but these reports of increased Morgana raiding activity have to take priority.
As much as I adore the work I am doing, Capitaine, I do enjoy getting back to my real job.
No intent to retire and join the Public Affairs Office, then? Good, I need you out here...
And? You trailed off. What were you going to say?
...Ah. Well. I'd miss you if you went off somewhere else.
Capitaine! Shh... someone might hear and misunderstand if you say such things.
Mist! Mist on the horizon!
Action stations!
@BATTLE
They were quite tenacious. More so than the normal raiders.

Fields.MenuText: I wonder... maybe Despair is back in the area.
Could this present a problem for the event?
I know I've said it before, but could they just die already? Turn your back for a second and there's more of them, like cockroaches with guns.

Fields.DialogueText: I certainly hope not. We haven't heard any broadcasts yet... but if it is her... it would explain the changes to their behavior.
It may well do so. I'll have to look at it in detail.
Hehehe. Say that over the radio and the more vain amongst the Morganas will have a grudge with you personally, Capitaine.
Morganas. Always hiding in their uglier sisters' shadows...
See that you do. I'd hate for your efforts to be wrecked.
Let them come. I've got an ace up my sleeve.
...we are endless like the tides. Only fools dare resist us, for every one of our sisters you sink... she returns, stronger than before! You have...
Enough! Turn that noise off!
Aye, Ma'am.
I guess Despair not coming back was a little too much to hope for.
Oui... I wish to fasten my hands around her throat. Her voice grates on my heart and my ears.
Should we start trying to jam them, Captain? We should have all the right equipment.

Fields.MenuText: On the double, sailor, and make the signal loud as hell. I want to damage their equipment if at all possible.
Hmm... the usual way to jam things involves loud music, right? See if we have a record with some bagpipe music somewhere onboard.
Let's hold off for now. We can surprise her later.

Fields.DialogueText: Will do!
I'm sure someone has got something we can use. I think there's a couple Scotsmen in engineering.
Understood. I'll get everything in place and be ready to transmit on your order.
What are you planning, Capitaine?
I think it's quite obvious that Despair is here for us, or more specifically you. She's going to come find us. I want to be ready to give her a bloody nose when she does.
I'll coordinate with the others and ensure the fleet is battle ready. She'll not find us caught off guard!
*ALARM*
Damn. She's not the only one with tricks to spare.
@BATTLE
Morganas inbound!
Action stations!
I can see the fleet coming over the horizon... wait. They're coming to a halt, Captain! They're holding position at the edge of our vision.
What the hell are they up to now?
Capitaine, come to the radio room! You should hear this!
What is it? We're about to engage the enemy.
...Surrender and only your Belles will be smashed! Surrender and spare your lives, humans. Come to me... it is inevitable. Be mine in life. Or in death.
Cut it off. I've heard enough. A demand to surrender, eh?
She must think quite highly of herself. We savaged her forces last time.

Fields.MenuText: Is she still broadcasting?
From what we can see of her fleet... I don't think we're in that much trouble.
We need to transmit something before we engage. We can't let an insult like that stand on dead air.

Fields.DialogueText: Does she ever stop?
Non. She vastly overestimates herself, or has grown wildly stronger.
So many lovely responses to consider... it's hard to pick.
If I may, Capitaine, I would like to respond to this Despair's demand for our surrender. A traditional French response to such things.
Carry on then.
Aye sir... transmitting... "Merde!"
That's the spirit. Now, transmit to all ships! Attack! And start jamming Despair's transmissions.
Truly a traditional response, sailor. Now let's make her eat her words.
@BATTLE
Now that we know Despair is back in the area, we might need to change our plans for fleet weekend.
I was just thinking about that. Operational and recreational security are tantamount to our mission. I want to let the sailors get some shore leave in, too.
I am open to any ideas you might have, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Well, the simplest seems to be to split our fleet and the support fleet from the INPF in two. First fleet makes port the first day, the second the second.
We weren't going to be able to dock everyone anyway, even at the largest of France's deep-water ports. There's merchant traffic and normal French naval forces to consider.
If anything, physically defending the port we're entertaining at underlines our point. There's still a threat out there.

Fields.DialogueText: That would be most efficient. Keep the second force anchored just outside the port and maybe have a small squadron patrolling.
A fair point. There are only so many piers we can use.
Yes you're quite right. I'd prefer that the Morgana don't crash our soirée... but I just know Despair won't be able to resist.
We'll have to prepare some drills to scramble the fleet. That kind of thing.
Of course, Despair will likely throw quite a force at us.
Prepare documentation to that effect. I want all ships and captains briefed well before we kick this party off.
Hmm... just what is the appropriate amount of torpedoes to bring to a black tie affair? Speaking of... I've prepared your dress uniform. For both days.
Of course you have. Both days?
Not to worry, I'll dress up as well. We have to make a good impression on our guests.
*ALARM*
And these guests?
Our Sunday worst.
@BATTLE
Capitaine! Dispatches for you!
Right... oh, this one's for you, Triomphant. Looks pretty important. That's quite the seal on the back.
What could it... oh. Capitaine! I wrote to the Americans for advice on fleet week. This is the response, but it's from... President Roosevelt!
That makes sense on some level. He did originate the tradition, after all. What's it say?
Some general advice and encouragement, and an order for us to show the colors of united humanity to the common man. Easier to say for a nation protected by two oceans, I suppose.
But exactly what I'm trying to do all the same. He also says that he'll personally attend the first INPF fleet week to be held in a US port!
Sounds like you have his seal of approval, then.

Fields.MenuText: Anything else in there? Offers of material support, maybe?
Interesting that he responded personally. Or even personally enough to have a secretary write it for him.
I think that proves we're on the right track.

Fields.DialogueText: No, just moral support, but I think that is enough for now. I'm sure the Americans will engage quite positively for fleet events held on their soil.
Indeed. I'm... rather proud of our little idea, if I'm honest.
Oui, we have found the road to success. Now we must succeed.
*ALARM*
We have the support we need. Now we just have to live to use it.
@BATTLE
Triomphant. I have a very important question for you. We've been planning fleet week for a while now, but have we actually selected a port?
Oh! Pardon, Capitaine, I thought I had told you! We're going to make for the deep-water port of Cherbourg.
It has a sizable port, a significant presence of the French Navy, and a strong maritime tradition. We can also bring all of our ships in without issue.
Because it's a major commercial hub there are many roads in and out, well-traveled and in good condition.

Fields.MenuText: I'd assume they have port defenses at Cherbourg. Will they be any help?
That'll give us a fair bit of room to move in and out.
What about getting the word out to the local area?

Fields.DialogueText: Not even slightly, though it's nice to think about.
Yes, it's quite a spacious port. I've visited there before.
The local garrison commander has already started sending out messengers with posters to the outlying villages.
Sounds like everything is all lined up, then.
Indeed, everything's falling into place. It's beautiful on some level. I've been working so hard towards all this, and it's starting to come together.
I feel like there's a glut of last-minute paperwork just waiting to happen.
...Capitaine, did you really have to say something? Now that you've jinxed me, you'll be helping me with that paperwork!
Get the Morganas to help. I think we're about to engage.
Non, Capitaine. Even them I would not wish it on.
@BATTLE
What's all this paperwork you're dumping on my desk?
I told you you were going to help me with all this! You just had to say something, Capitaine.
But there's so much... ugh. This is way beyond what I was thinking.
Docking permits for every ship in the fleet, orders and a docking permit for the cargo ship bringing in the supplies, contracts for said supplies...
... The list goes on. Extensively. Requisitions for uniform items, national and INPF flags, fuel, ammunition, those fireworks you wanted...
Hoisted by my own petard in a slightly literal sense of the term. Wait, why is the paperwork for the fireworks as thick as my wrist!?
Well there's the various permits, transport permits, contracts with the specialists to set the display up, the contracts to acquire the materials themselves...
Stop. Stop. I get it. Goddamn it.
You need to sign most of this any way, so you'd have needed to be in here with me regardless.

Fields.MenuText: Well, as long as I'm spending time with you, it can't be all that bad.
This is going to take far longer than I want to think about.
There's got to be ways to mitigate some of this nonsense.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine... please. You can't just say things like that! Even in private. Someone... might get the wrong idea.
That is why we shall do it together.
We could light some of it on fire. That would make HQ very upset, though.
Wait... Capitaine... I... Morganas! We need to get to the bridge!
Guess we're taking a break before we even get started!
@BATTLE
Ah... at last! Avec cela, nous avons fini! We are done!
Frozen bowels of hell that took an ungodly amount of time.
It did. But we are done, and now there is more work to do. It requires my hull cutting through the water, not a pen scratching on the page.
Walk me through what's next?
We will form up and meet the supply ship and the support fleet from the INPF. Then we will sail to Cherbourg in standard convoy formation.
Then we start fleet weekend!
That's it? That's really it?
You have become so paranoid, Capitaine! Surely this hasn't been all that complicated! It is much easier than a military campaign, for example.

Fields.MenuText: I've learned to be appropriately wary of Belle projects.
I'll relax once the job's done.
It's really just an excuse to keep my flag aboard you.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph. I'll make sure some of the other Belles hear about that if that's how you feel about it.
You must relax now. You will not get the chance once we get under way. Take your chances when they present themselves, Capitaine.
Capitaine! I keep telling you. Saying things like that... I... er. Someone might get the wrong impression.
Still, I think this calls for a glass of wine. Care to join me?
I'd join you for a drink regardless, but after all of that work? Definitely.
*ALARM*
Real teetotalers, those Morganas.
Militantly so, Capitaine. Ironic that they drive people to drink, no?
@BATTLE
I have the reports from the fleet. All ships are in formation and we're proceeding to Cherbourg.
The supply ship might just be the most heavily defended merchant vessel in the history of naval power.
If the Morganas are going to try anything they'll throw enough at us to make a solid go for it. Let's hope the lookouts stay tight instead of daydreaming about pretty French girls.
What about you, Capitaine? Will you take this time to daydream about pretty French girls?
I spend most of my time with a pretty French girl these days, so why should I daydream?
I shall warn you a third and final time, Capitaine, to be careful what you say... I might misunderstand your meaning, you know.
I think I'm pretty unambiguous in my meaning, Triomphant. Unless there's another French redhead who inhabits a destroyer hull around here.
Well. In that case, you may continue to praise me. Flattery will get you everywhere, you know.

Fields.MenuText: Why should I flatter you? Flattery is empty, and I can compliment you honestly.
I thought the phrase went "Flattery will get you nowhere."
Triomphant, you're blushing again.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm... well played. You may continue with your compliments.
But of course flattery doesn't get you anywhere... outside of very special conditions for the flatterer and the flattered.
Perhaps we should walk down to sick bay and get you looked at. You're clearly seeing things.
*ALARM*
Right on time. I knew they couldn't resist such a large convoy.
Let us make them regret their  choices!
@BATTLE
You know, Capitaine, I didn't expect you to have us on sentry duty first.
Work before play. Besides, it sets a good example if the boss stands sentinel while others go on shore leave.
Well, I shan't complain for the company, and I can hear all the ruckus from here!
Certainly sounds busy. The local garrison's band seems to be dueling with the INPF's.
It is a bit silly, but it seems the French navy doesn't want to be entirely outdone in their own port. Some of their crews have joined the sporting contests.
Good. A bit of levity will help everyone, and we need to stay on good terms with all our parent navies. Especially when we're borrowing port space.
The neutrality will only become harder, won't it?
It was always destined to go that way, even before the treaty was formalized. Imagine how some of the crew must feel.
All this power we Belles have, our homelands will look to us to act in their defense. Against other humans we must answer no, but that doesn't mean we don't wish to.

Fields.MenuText: Do you wish to? Peel the neutrality stripes off your hull and go to the defense of France?
An old chief petty officer I used to know liked to say "If wishes were horses, beggars would ride."
I think about home all the time... but I have to trust others to settle the squabbles of humankind. If the Morganas win...

Fields.DialogueText: I... no. In the end, no. With this much power... this strength. This is why we have capitaines. You are our moral compass to we who are somewhat adrift.
He seems like a wise old salt indeed.
Yes, they are the greater threat, to all mankind. Though I wonder about the evils of man in comparison to them sometimes when I see the headlines.
Why are we sitting around like this? Let us review the tour together, and then get something to eat!
There's far better things to be doing than gathering flies with our mouths.
*ALARM*
Case in point.
We are here for a reason. Duty calls!
@BATTLE
Bienvenue à bord, comme ça s'il vous plaît. I am Triomphant and it's a pleasure to have you as my guests. The sailor will show you around. This way, thank you.
We've had a lot of crowds.
Well, of course. I am a French ship in a French port. Such "open houses" are not common even for people who live around here.
Fair point. It's not often that civilians are invited aboard warships of any kind.
Madame, avez-vous besoin d'aide? Do you need help?
Don't mind me, dear, I was just a bit nostalgic. Lovely young couples like you always make me remember when I was your age.
Madame, I think you've misunderstood.
Nonsense, child. I remember when I was standing... not quite in your place, but next to my own charming young officer all the same... he was right, though.
About the spirits of warships, that is. He joked about his ship being his other lover. Perhaps this Captain is smart enough to cut out the third party, eh?
I have been around the Navy my entire life. Born in Brest, marrying a bright young officer, and eventually ending up here in Cherbourg... and I always believed in you too.
Toutes nos félicitations. Je vous souhaite à tous les deux le bonheur du monde!
Oh dear, that was quite the misunderstanding. Was I standing closer to you than was strictly proper?

Fields.MenuText: Does the thought upset you that much, Triomphant?
I don't know. To outside eyes we probably do look like a handsome young couple.
What was that last thing she said?

Fields.DialogueText: No, it doesn't... it's not like that. It was just a bit sudden, is all.  I wasn't expecting someone to say anything like that.
You know, we are dressed up nicely, and we clearly have excellent rapport with each other even to outside eyes. A certain... intimacy perhaps. We have become close after all.
It... is a traditional French blessing for newlyweds. I wish you both all the happiness in the world.
Let's catch up with the tour group... and since we are a young couple, apparently, would you do me the honor of taking my arm?
Since you ask so politely Capitaine... no!
I can't be that poor of a date.
No, it's... I'm sensing Morganas. They're far away, but there's so many.
Do we have time to evacuate?
We'll make time, Capitaine. They're going to need our help out there.
@BATTLE
Captain! Enemy contact reported, sir! They're engaging the picket line again!
Sound recall. The second the majority of the crew are back on board I want us casting off and making flank speed for the enemy!
Aye-aye, sir!
*ALARM*
Capitaine! There are still civilians aboard! I can feel them! What should we do?

Fields.MenuText: No time. Get them somewhere safe below!
Priority to getting the civilians off the ship via the ramps. Then get the crew on!
Put the civilians over the side in one of the lifeboats. That way we won't have to tie up the boarding gantry with traffic both ways.

Fields.DialogueText: I know just the spot. I'll go at once and join you on the bridge!
Of course, Capitaine. I'll pass the orders.
Brilliant, Capitaine. I'll see to it myself.
Right... status?
Crew's getting into position. We kept her warm so we'd be ready to get under way the second we cast off.
Right, let's get this done. The fleet needs our help, and Despair is probably out there somewhere waiting for us!
And I just can't abide party crashers.
@BATTLE
Capitaine! We found her! Bring us in to engage!
There you are, Triomphant! Your ensign will make a trophy after I crush you! Your struggles mean nothing, and you mean nothing. I am inevitable!
@BATTLE
I doubt she's learned her lesson, but I hope she'll stay away long enough for us to conclude today's festivities.
I doubt she's going to learn some manners from having her hide tanned again, but we should have bought some time to finish fleet week.
Speaking of that... since we're on our way back to port, would you care to join me for the fireworks later?
I have secured a bottle of champagne and ensured that the lookout post will be unoccupied. I wish to toast our successful event, and another defeat of Despair.
On multiple fronts.
All the more reason to celebrate, Capitaine.
Well, I think my schedule's clear this evening. I'll try and pencil me in.
You cannot fool me, Capitaine! I saw your smile when I invited you.
You've got quite the smile right now, too. You look like the cat that's caught the canary. Something I should know?
I'm sure you'll find out soon enough, Capitaine. I'll see you later... and keep the dress uniform. That old woman was right. You do look quite dashing in it.

Fields.MenuText: Hmm... that's... intriguing... seems it's going to be a lovely day after all, even with Despair's interruption.
I'm suddenly a bit nervous. That's odd. Why the hell am I nervous?
Better make sure my uniform still looks good and freshen up a bit.

Fields.DialogueText: I think you're right, Captain.
I'm sorry, Captain. Were you speaking to me?
Right away, Captain!
Le Triomphant arriving!
Excuse me, Captain, do you have any orders to pass to the crew?
Ah, Chief, good timing. Secure all stations and sound liberty call. All hands are to turn to for shore leave. Be a shame to miss our own party, after all.
Right you are, sir. Mademoiselle Triomphant went to all this trouble for us.
That she did, Chief. Find some of the sailors who didn't make it to the ship in time to engage Despair and recall them for watch standing. Everyone else is to enjoy themselves.
You and the Belle enjoy yourselves too, Captain.
You have my permission to keep it under your hat.
